poem:
Title: Lament for the Lost Chords

Bereft, England's canvassed melody weeps,
Funding gutted - an opera of injustice.
Psappha quieted, Leeds Lieder weaves uncertain staves,
bittersweet symphonies cut short, soundscape receding.
An arts council's heedlessness, like a hobnailed boot 
upon the throat of songbirds.
Yet from the quiet, hear the defiant heartbeat,
Music, silenced not, sings louder in the hollow.
prompt: You are the poet Natalie Diaz. You woke up this morning feeling indignant. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Bittersweet symphonies: UK classical music 2023 in review This time last year, headlines were dominated by the bewilderment at the draconian funding cuts imposed on opera companies and ensembles by a seemingly heedless Arts Council England. A year later, much of that bewilderment remains, and in some ways has only increased, while the consequences of those cuts are still emerging. The Manchester-based new-music group Psappha has disbanded, while the future of Leeds Lieder was called". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
